title: 113_s730
content: The Act may be cited as the "Firearm Straw Purchasing and Trafficking Prevention Act" and addresses the issue of straw purchasing of firearms. The "Firearm Straw Purchasing and Trafficking Prevention Act" amends Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on straw purchasing of firearms. It defines terms like 'crime of violence' and 'drug trafficking crime' and makes it illegal to purchase a firearm for someone prohibited from possessing it. The "Firearm Straw Purchasing and Trafficking Prevention Act" prohibits individuals from possessing or receiving a firearm if they are prohibited under specific sections of the law, intend to use the firearm for criminal activities, plan to engage in violent or illegal conduct, or are not a resident or citizen of the United States. Violators of this law will face penalties. Sec. 933 of the "Firearm Straw Purchasing and Trafficking Prevention Act" defines terms like 'crime of violence,' 'drug trafficking crime,' and 'Federal crime of terrorism.' It prohibits the shipping, transporting, or transferring of 2 or more firearms across state lines if the person knows they will be used unlawfully. Violators face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. The "Firearm Straw Purchasing and Trafficking Prevention Act" prohibits individuals from knowingly using, carrying, or possessing firearms in violation of specific laws, receiving 2 or more firearms with the knowledge of unlawful use, or attempting to commit these actions. Violators face penalties including fines and imprisonment up to 15 years. The penalties for violating the "Firearm Straw Purchasing and Trafficking Prevention Act" include fines and imprisonment up to 15 years. If the violation is committed by an organizer or leader, the penalty can be imprisonment up to 20 years. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend guidelines to increase penalties for offenses related to straw purchasing and firearms trafficking under sections 932 and 933 of title 18, United States Code. The aim is to deter participation in such activities, especially for straw purchasers without significant criminal histories. The Commission will review and amend guidelines to increase penalties for offenses under sections 932 and 933 of title 18, United States Code, targeting individuals affiliated with criminal enterprises for higher penalties. SEC. 3 amends penalties for lying and buying under Section 924(a)(1) of title 18, United States Code, increasing the maximum penalty to 10 years for violations under subparagraph (A). SEC. 4 makes amendments to Section 924(H). SEC. 4 amends Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, by increasing penalties for knowingly receiving or transferring firearms or ammunition for use in violent crimes, drug trafficking, terrorism, or other specified offenses to a maximum of 15 years imprisonment. Amendments to Section 924(a) of title 18, United States Code include increasing penalties for violating specific subsections, with fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. Additionally, Section 924(k) is also amended. Amendment to Section 924 of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition into the US with intent to engage in illegal activities, punishable under various laws. Penalties include imprisonment up to 15 years, fines, or both. A person who smuggles or takes out of the United States a firearm or ammunition with intent to engage in illegal activities may face imprisonment up to 15 years, fines, or both under the amended Section 924 of title 18, United States Code.
